DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Facility has sold. No longer responsible for RMP

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

A?    California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
A?    Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR A?68
A?    California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR A?5189
A?    Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR A?1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Anchor Warehouse Services has elected to use PSMWriter;, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1    ANCHOR WAREHOUSE SERVICES, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Anchor Warehouse Services has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Ammonia Refrigeration - Anhydrous Ammonia - 18,000 lb

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.

Anchor Warehouse Services has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1.    Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to m

eet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2.    Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Anchor Warehouse Services business practices
3.    Utilized PSMWriter© software to ensure that all necessary Anchor Warehouse Services employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.

1.2    PROCESS DESCRIPTION

Anchor Warehouse Services is a commercial cold storage facility.  The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to five (5) cold storage rooms, three (3) precool rooms, and one (1) hallway.  The cold storage and precool rooms are equipped with spiral and plate fin bunker coils, while the hallway has two (2) ceiling suspended coils.  Both kinds of coils contain chilled liquid ammonia.

The system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from a high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room where it passes through a solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into a low pressure accumulator vessel mounted inside the bunkers.  Low temperature liquid circulates by thermal convection through the evaporator coils located behind bunker walls in the cold rooms.  Low pressure and temperature gas collects in the accumulator vessel, and passes through a pressure regulator into a suction line.  The suction line returns the vapor to the main suction accumulator vessel located in the engine room, which separates any residual liquid from the gas.  The gas is piped to reciprocating which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receivers. Liquid separated from the suction return gas in the main suction accumulator vessel drains into a liquid transfer vessel.  Operation of a float switch activated

solenoid valve raises the pressure in the liquid transfer vessel to the point the liquid can be drained into the high pressure receiver.  

The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.  

The ammonia system at this facility consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected.  Therefore, the system is treated as a single process.

1.3    GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

1.3.1    GENERAL 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Anchor Warehouse Services has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program. 

1.3.2    ANHYDROUS AMMONIA

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Anchor Warehouse Services facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration c

ontractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Anchor Warehouse Services has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5    EMERGENCY ACTION AND RESPONSE PLAN

Anchor Warehouse Services' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

A?    California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR A?3220
A?    Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR A?1910.38 
A?    California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 A?5192(q)
A?    Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR A?1910.120(q)

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Our company has an outstanding safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Many policies and procedures have been implemented to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Anchor Warehouse Services continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter; software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Anchor Warehouse Services' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter; tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Anchor Warehouse Services' management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Anchor Warehouse Services has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is comp

leted (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter;, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter© as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter;.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter; to create, schedule, track, and document events, Anchor Warehouse Services has also entered into a contract with California Controlled Atmosphere to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of California Controlled Atmosphere's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.
For the future, Anchor Warehouse Services now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Anchor Warehouse Services employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Anchor Warehouse Services will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
